articles.headline: Pfizer Shares Plummet on Loss of a Promising Heart Drug
articles.snippet: Investors send shares of Pfizer down almost 11 percent in response to company's decision to end development of heart medication Torcetrapib; analysts say company needs to accelerate efforts to cut costs and develop new profit-making drugs; current...
articles.abstract: Investors send shares of Pfizer down almost 11 percent in response to company's decision to end development of heart medication Torcetrapib; analysts say company needs to accelerate efforts to cut costs and develop new profit-making drugs; current position in industry is strong but important patents will soon run out causing billions of dollars in losses; Pfizer is likely to use acquisitions and licensing deals to ensure its future; photo; graph (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Can a company expecting about $50 billion in sales and $12 billion in profits this year really be in trouble? Investors seem to think so.
articles.byline: By Alex Berenson and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: Votes in Doubt, Bolton Resigns as Ambassador
articles.snippet: Pres Bush reluctantly accepts John R Bolton's resignation of United Nations ambassador, conceding that he cannot win Senate confirmation; Bush issues statement, excoriating Bolton's opponents on Senate Foreign Relations Committee and praising Bolt...
articles.abstract: Pres Bush reluctantly accepts John R Bolton's resignation of United Nations ambassador, conceding that he cannot win Senate confirmation; Bush issues statement, excoriating Bolton's opponents on Senate Foreign Relations Committee and praising Bolton, outspoken conservative and longtime critic of UN; Bolton's critics say he is abrasive, rigid conservative at odds with UN spirit of diplomacy; his supporters point to his successes with several UN Security Council resolutions; Bolton's recess appointment expires at end of 2006; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 - President Bush reluctantly accepted the resignation of the United Nations ambassador, John R. Bolton, on Monday, conceding that the envoy could not win Senate confirmation and signaling that the administration was unwilling to make another end run around Congressional opponents in order to keep Mr. Bolton in his job.

articles.headline: Court Reviews Race as Factor in School Plans
articles.snippet: Supreme Court hears arguments in case against two public schools that use student-assignment plans to maintain racial integration, and lawyers for schools face hostile scrutiny from court's new majority; two school systems, in Louisville, Ky, and ...
articles.abstract: Supreme Court hears arguments in case against two public schools that use student-assignment plans to maintain racial integration, and lawyers for schools face hostile scrutiny from court's new majority; two school systems, in Louisville, Ky, and Seattle, offer students choice of schools but can deny admission based on race if student's enrollment would upset racial balance; debate among justices is whether measures designed to maintain integration should be subjected to same scrutiny as efforts to maintain segregation were subjected to in Brown v Board of Education; lawyers for school systems find themselves challenged to explain why plans should be seen as different from intentional segregation since both are assignments based on race; many school districts are thought to use similar plans where residential patterns would produce schools of one race; court decision could potentially affect hundreds of districts (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 - By the time the Supreme Court finished hearing arguments on Monday on the student-assignment plans that two urban school systems use to maintain racial integration, the only question was how far the court would go in ruling such plans unconstitutional.

articles.headline: Offering Video, Israel Answers Critics on War
articles.snippet: Israel is using photographs and video to buttress its accusation that Hezbollah systematically fired from civilian neighborhoods in southern Lebanon.
articles.abstract: Israel is using photographs and video to buttress its accusation that Hezbollah systematically fired from civilian neighborhoods in southern Lebanon.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, Dec. 4 — Israel’s military, which has been accused of abuses in its war against Hezbollah this summer, has declassified photographs, video images and prisoner interrogations to buttress its accusation that Hezbollah systematically fired from civilian neighborhoods in southern Lebanon and took cover in those areas to shield itself from attack.

articles.headline: 2nd Official Dissented Over Pequot Inquiry
articles.snippet: Eric Ribelin is second Securities and Exchange commission official to express serious concerns about how agency conducted into Pequot Capital Management hedge fund; will testify in inquiry examining allegations that agency prematurely ended invest...
articles.abstract: Eric Ribelin is second Securities and Exchange commission official to express serious concerns about how agency conducted into Pequot Capital Management hedge fund; will testify in inquiry examining allegations that agency prematurely ended investigation due to political pressure (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Congressional investigators have found that a second official at the Securities and Exchange Commission expressed serious concerns about how the agency was conducting its inquiry into a prominent hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management.

articles.headline: Bank of New York and Mellon Will Merge
articles.snippet: The $16.5 billion deal will create a securities-processing powerhouse in a little-noticed corner of the financial world.
articles.abstract: The $16.5 billion deal will create a securities-processing powerhouse in a little-noticed corner of the financial world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of New York and Mellon Financial of Pittsburgh have agreed to merge in a $16.5 billion deal that will create a securities-processing powerhouse in a little-noticed corner of the financial world.

articles.headline: NASA Plans Permanent Moon Base
articles.snippet: NASA announces plans for permanent base on Moon; NASA officials say rudimentary base could be set up soon after astronauts return to Moon in 2020; after base is established, other countries and commercial enterprises could expand outpost; NASA giv...
articles.abstract: NASA announces plans for permanent base on Moon; NASA officials say rudimentary base could be set up soon after astronauts return to Moon in 2020; after base is established, other countries and commercial enterprises could expand outpost; NASA gives no cost estimate for program, but says money could be shifted to lunar exploration program from retired shuttle fleet and International Space Station; lunar base plan is first proposal of permanent presence on Moon; plan is part of larger effort to develop international exploration strategy; diagram of basic station components (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 - NASA announced plans on Monday for a permanent base on the Moon, to be started soon after astronauts return there around 2020.

articles.headline: As Auto Prosperity Shifts South, Two Towns Offer a Study in Contrasts
articles.snippet: Two towns, one in Michigan and one in Kentucky, show the effects of the U.S. auto industry, and the prosperity that accompanies it, shifting to the south.
articles.abstract: Two towns, one in Michigan and one in Kentucky, show the effects of the U.S. auto industry, and the prosperity that accompanies it, shifting to the south.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, Livonia, Mich., was a prosperous Detroit suburb, with upscale neighborhoods and high-end stores in a new mall selling Hermès and Chanel, which some locals wore on special occasions to dine at the romantic Fonte D’Amore restaurant.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Votes in Doubt, Bolton Resigns as Ambassador
articles.snippet: The administration was unwilling to make another end run around Congressional opponents to keep John R. Bolton.
articles.abstract: The administration was unwilling to make another end run around Congressional opponents to keep John R. Bolton.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 — President Bush reluctantly accepted the resignation of the United Nations ambassador, John R. Bolton, on Monday, conceding that the envoy could not win Senate confirmation and signaling that the administration was unwilling to make another end run around Congressional opponents in order to keep Mr. Bolton in his job.

articles.headline: Pfizer Shares Plummet on Loss of a Promising Heart Drug
articles.snippet: Pfizer’s stock fell almost 11 percent on Monday in a trading frenzy that shaved more than $21 billion off its market value.
articles.abstract: Pfizer’s stock fell almost 11 percent on Monday in a trading frenzy that shaved more than $21 billion off its market value.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can a company expecting about $50 billion in sales and $12 billion in profits this year really be in trouble? Investors seem to think so.
articles.byline: By Alex Berenson and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: 2nd Official Dissented Over Pequot Inquiry
articles.snippet: An investigator had serious misgivings about decisions being made on the case by senior S.E.C. officials.
articles.abstract: An investigator had serious misgivings about decisions being made on the case by senior S.E.C. officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congressional investigators have found that a second official at the Securities and Exchange Commission expressed serious concerns about how the agency was conducting its inquiry into a prominent hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management.

articles.headline: Bank of New York and Mellon Will Merge
articles.snippet: Bank of New York and Mellon Financial agree to merge in $16.5 billion deal; merged company will keep track of more than $16.6 trillion worth of assets with expanded international presence; deal may prompt new wave of consolidation in fragmented in...
articles.abstract: Bank of New York and Mellon Financial agree to merge in $16.5 billion deal; merged company will keep track of more than $16.6 trillion worth of assets with expanded international presence; deal may prompt new wave of consolidation in fragmented industry; photo; chart (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of New York and Mellon Financial of Pittsburgh have agreed to merge in a $16.5 billion deal that will create a securities-processing powerhouse in a little-noticed corner of the financial world.

articles.headline: Offering Video, Israel Answers Critics on War
articles.snippet: Israel releases photos, video images and prisoner interrogations in effort to prove its allegations that Hezbollah fired from civilian neighborhoods in southern Lebanon during war this summer; Lebanon and international human rights groups have acc...
articles.abstract: Israel releases photos, video images and prisoner interrogations in effort to prove its allegations that Hezbollah fired from civilian neighborhoods in southern Lebanon during war this summer; Lebanon and international human rights groups have accused Israel of war crimes, accusing its military of killing and recklessly endangering Lebanese civilians in its pursuit of Hezbollah; Israel counters that Hezbhollah systematically fired from civilian areas, itself war crime, and made areas legitimate targets; new report, by private Israeli research group, says Hezbollah stored weapons in mosques, fought from inside empty public buildings, flew white flags while transporting missiles and launched rockets near United Nations monitoring posts; Hezbollah official denies report's allegations, saying its military came into populated areas only when it was unavoidable; photos (M)

articles.headline: As Auto Prosperity Shifts South, Two Towns Offer a Study in Contrasts
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley
